text.p: Lehman Brothers said it expects Indigo to lose $0.94 a share in 1997 against its previous forecast of an $0.85 loss even though the company's third quarter 1996 loss was smaller than expected.
Indigo, an Israeli maker of digital printing systems, lost $0.26 a share in the third quarter, better than the $0.32 deficit Lehman had predicted.

Lehman analyst Theodor Kundtz maintained his fourth-quarter 1996 estimate of a $0.30-a-share loss but revised his full-year 1997 estimate to a $0.94 loss to reflect "uncertain shipment levels to Japanese distributors".
He estimated the company will lose $1.39 a share in 1996.
"Indigo should have ample cash to fund the business through 1997 (and) should reach profitability in 1998," Kundtz said in a report.

Lehman maintained its 3-Neutral rating. "We are encouraged to hear that utilisation and reliability of systems in the field appears to be steadily improving but we believe it will take some time before this translates to an upsurge in new machine orders," the report said.
